Thecovariance, $\delta,$ captures the unobserved factors that affect both the economic valuation and the post-investment economic performance (Sorensen, 2007). For instance, a company with a strong management team possesses a better potential economic performance. This characteristic was unobserved in our data, but it can be observed partly by the VC firm at the time of the investment decision. Since the characteristic also increases the company's rate of successful exit, it enters the error terms in both valuation and outcome equations. In Section 5.1.1, we will elaborate on how the sign of the covariance reveals the preference over the characteristics unobserved in our data.  

### 3.2. Interaction of VC investment decisions, estimation, and identification  

In the one-to-many matching model, once the focal VC invests in a company as a lead VC, the other VCs are precluded from making further investments in the same company as a lead VC. Such an interaction means that each VC's investment decision cannot be analyzed in isolation. The commonly used Probit estimation cannot account for the interactions among different VCs, so it is not applicable in this case (Sorensen, 2007). Instead, Bayesian estimation using MCMC simulation provides an elegant solution. The simulation relies on the pair-wise stability of the equilibrium matching: VCs and companies receive higher economic values from the observed matches than they would otherwise have obtained from counterfactual matches, and neither matched pairs nor unmatched pairs prefer to deviate from the observed matching and form a new match. Therefore, the pair-wise stability imposes a lower bound for the economic value of any observed match and an upper bound for the economic value of any counterfactual match.  

$$
\bar{V}_{i j}\equiv m a x\left[V_{\mu(j)j},\mathop{m i n}_{j\in\mu(i)}V_{i j}\right]
$$  

$$
\mathbb{\underline{{V}}}_{i j}\equiv m a x\left[{m a x}V_{i j},{m a x}V_{i j}\right]
$$  

where  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{S(i)\equiv\left\{j\in J:V_{i j}>V_{\mu(j)j}\right\}}}\ {{{}}}\ {{S(j)\equiv\left\{i\in I:V_{i j}>\underset{j\in\mu(i)}{m i n}V_{i j}\right\}}}\end{array}
$$  

More specifically, we simultaneously estimate the valuation equation and outcome equation using Bayesian estimation based on MCMC simulation. For brevity, let $\alpha$ contain the parameters of valuation equation and $\beta$ contain the parameters of the outcome equation. The MCMC process treats latent variables as parameters along with $(\alpha,\beta,\delta)$ , which significantly simplifies simulation of the resulting augmented posterior distribution. The simulation process is iterative, with each iteration generating a draw from a Markov Chain. The Markov chain is generated by drawing each individual dimension of the joint posterior distribution, conditioned on the draws of the other dimensions. As shown in Sorensen (2007)'s Appendix, with a normal prior distribution of $(\alpha,\beta,\delta)$ , the univariate conditional posterior distributions of $\alpha,\beta,\delta$ and latent variables $V_{i j}$ for all $\ddot{\imath\jmath}$ are also normal or truncated normal. When $i j$ is a matched pair, $V_{i j}$ is truncated from below at $\underline{{V}}_{i j}$ .When $i j$ is an unmatched pair, $V_{i j}$ is truncated from above at $\bar{V}_{i j}$ . Thus, the draws of $V_{i j}$ (for all $i j$ satisfy pair-wise stability, and account for the equilibrium matching between VCs and companies.  

Bayesian estimation recovers the parameters consistently. The valuation equation is defined on the set of all potential matches, not just the set of observed matches. Thus, the error erm $\eta_{i j}$ is unrelated to explanation variables in the valuation equation, which, together with the draws of $V_{i j}$ (the dependent variable in the valuation equation), enables us to estimate $\alpha$ consistently. Unlike the valuation equation, the outcome equation is just defined on the set of observed matches. Its error term $\varepsilon_{i j}$ can be decomposed orthogonally into the sum of $\delta\eta_{i j}$ and $\zeta_{i j},$ in which $\delta$ is the covariance between $\varepsilon_{i j}$ and $\eta_{i j}$ (see Eq. (6)). In each iteration of the MCMC process, the disturbance $\eta_{i j}$ will be estimated first, so the remaining term $\zeta_{i j}$ is the real error term of the outcome equation. Since $\zeta_{i j}$ is unrelated to the test variable $G V C$ and $\eta_{i j}$ , the Bayesian estimators for the coefficient $\beta_{1}$ on GVC and the covariance $\delta$ are also consistent. We use the "matchingMarkets" package in $R$ to carry out our estimation routine.  

### 3.3.Additional model and variables  

Section 2.2 implies that companies with inferior potential economic performance are likely to be underfunded by PVCs, even though they might engage in intensive innovation. However, some of the innovative companies neglected by PVCs could be funded by GVCs, since GVCs bear the social mission of increasing social value stemming from innovation. It is difficult to directly test whether GVC-funded companies are potentially innovative. Thus, we investigate this conjecture indirectly by examining whether the potential innovativeness of GVC-funded companies is higher than that of PVC-funded companies. To do so, we reconstruct the outcome equation as follows:

In this equation, Patent is the logarithm of one plus the number of patent applications within two years after the first funding round (Ke and Wang, 2021). Patenting is used extensively to measure post-investment innovative performance, since it is highly correlated with successful innovation. Chinese patents are classified into three categories, i.e., invention, utility model, and design. In the main test, we only include patent applications for inventions and utility models because design patents generally are low in innovation quality (Ke and Wang, 2021).  

We include the characteristics of VCs, companies, deals, and institutional environments as control variables in the outcome equation (Eq. (7)). The definitions of the variables GVC, VC reputation, VC experience, VC network, VC limited partner, Early stage, High tech, Prior patent, Funding size, Staged investment, Investor size, Mixed syndication, Mixed co-financing, Year dummies, Region dummies are the same as those in Eq. (5). In addition, we include two control variables Local R&D and Legal protection. Local R&D is calculated as the natural logarithm of the R&D expenditure in the province in which the company is located, measured in the year of the first funding round. Legal protection is proxied by Wang et al. (2021)'s law environment index measured in the year of the first funding round (Ke and Wang, 2021). This index captures the development of market intermediaries, the strength of the legal environment safeguarding the market, and the level of intellectual property protection in the province where the company is located. The term $\epsilon_{i j}$ captures factors unobserved in our data.  

Similar to the analysis in section 3.1 and 3.2, the error term $\epsilon_{i j}$ of Eq. (7) can be decomposed orthogonally into $\psi\eta_{i j}$ and $\xi_{i j}$ where $\eta_{i j}$ is the error term of the valuation equation (Eq. (4)) and $\psi$ is the covariance between $\epsilon_{i j}$ and $\eta_{i j}$ The covariance, $\psi$ , captures unobserved factors that affect both economic valuation and post-investment innovative performance of a match. The sign of $\psi$ is to be determined, and it depends on whether innovative companies are, on average, associated with high economic values. A more detailed discussion of this is presented in Section 5.2. We estimate the valuation equation (Eq. (4) and outcome equation (Eq. (7)) simultaneously using Bayesian estimation based on the MCMC simulation method (Sorensen, 2007). The Bayesian estimators for the covariance $\psi$ and the coefficient $\gamma_{1}$ on GVC in Eq. (7) are consistent.  

## 4. Data  

### 4.1. Data collection and sample  

The work draws on data from the Chinese VC market. We collected information on VC investment deals, such as investment dates, investment amounts, names of VC firms, names of funded companies, stage of companies’ development and industry classification, primarily from the Zero2IPO database, which has been used extensively in research on the Chinese VC market and covers most VC investment deals in China after 1990 (e.g., Li et al., 2016). To measure companies' post-investment economic performance, we collected information on their exit via IPO or M&A in the same database.  

To identify GVCs and PVCs, we manually collected the information of VC firm shareholders. By searching for each VC firm's abbreviated name and full name on the website of China's State Administration for Industry and Commerce (SAIC) (http:/www.gsxt. gov.cn/), we collected information about the shareholders? ownership backgrounds and investment amounts.  

To collect the data on companies? post-investment innovative performance, we searched for their abbreviated and full names on the website of China's State Intellectual Property Rights Office (http:/www.cnipa.gov.cn/) and collected the annual patent application data.  

The original sample is restricted to the first-round investment for each company, and in the cases where several VC firms participate in this funding round, the sample includes only the investment by the lead VC firm. The lead VC firm is identified as the VC firm that makes the largest investment in the first round (Ke and Wang, 2021). The sample is restricted to first-round funding made from 2000 to 2014. We excluded the companies whose first-round funding deal concluded before 2ooo, because the Chinese VC market was still in its infancy in the 1990s, and this would have led to the inclusion of incomplete data (Zheng and Xia, 2018). We also excluded the companies whose first-round funding deal concluded after 2014, since most VC firms′ investment cycle is five to six years, and we needed to maintain a six-year observation window when collecting performance data. We stopped collecting data on the performance of companies in 2020. Following the literature, we removed the companies in the real estate development and film/television industries because a successful exit from these industries cannot be judged by IPO or M&A (Zhang and Mayes, 2018). We removed the first-round funding led by foreign venture capital firms due to different exit patterns between companies funded by foreign venture capital firms and those funded by domestic VC firms (Suchard et al., 2021). We also removed companies that had missing data. The final sample contains 3328 first-round funding deals, which involve 1298 lead VCs.

## 5. Findings  

### 5.1. Do GVCs crowd out PVCs?  

To explore whether GVCs crowd out PVCs in the stage of investment selection, we estimate the structural model composed of Eqs. (4) and (5). The structural model also enables us to test the VCs' and companies’ preferences over certain characteristics of each other. Table 3 reports the Bayesian estimation results of the structural model.  

#### 5.1.1. Verification of preference assumption  

The coefficients in the valuation equation in Table 3 indicate the agents preferences over the observed characteristics. The larger the coefficients, the stronger the preferences over the characteristics. As can be seen, the coefficient for GVC in the valuation equation is $-0.3181$ , and it is statistically significant at the $5\%$ level. The negative sign reflects that, other things being equal, GVCs are less preferred than PVCs by companies. 4 This finding suggests that although GVC investment could benefit companies in some aspects, such as assisting the companies in getting extra public support (Colombo et al., 2016; Suchard et al., 2021), its negative impacts on the companies operation, such as companies becoming less independent and lacking the power of negotiation concerning covenants, dominate companies' evaluation on GVCs (Cumming et al., 2017). The marginal effect of GVC in the valuation equation is $8.97\%$ It indicates that, given the identical experience, reputation, network position and organization form of VCs, the likelihood of GVCs being preferred by companies is $41.03\%$ $(50\%{-}8.97\%)$ . The probability would be $50\%$ if companies had no preference concerning VCs' ownership.  

The control variables in the valuation equation show interesting results. The coefficient for VC reputation is positive and significant at the $1\%$ level, suggesting that VC investors with more successful exit experiences are more likely to be selected by companies. However, the coefficient for VC experience is negative and significant at the $1\%$ level, indicating that VC investors with more rounds of financing experience are less likely to be chosen by companies as the lead VC. This finding remained after we tried multiple alternative measurements. The result may be attributed to the limited time the VCs are able to allocate to each project when they have many projects (Wang and Wang, 2011). The coefficient for Early stage is negative and significant at the $1\%$ level, indicating that earlier-stage companies are less likely to be selected by VCs.  

The covariance between the error terms captures factors unobserved in our data that affect both economic valuation and postinvestment economic performance measured by successful exit. If a VC prefers matching with a company that possesses better potential economic performance, as we assumed in Section 2.1, then the associated characteristics (e.g., a strong management team of the company) will be recognized in valuation, and the error term in the valuation equation is positive. Since companies′ potential economic performance is in line with their post-investment economic performance, the error term in the outcome equation should also be positive. #### 5.1.2. The existence of assortative matching  

In Section 5.1.1, we found that in the first funding round, other things being equal, VCs prefer companies with better potential economic performance, and companies prefer PVCs over GVCs. Taken together, the revealed preferences indicate that GVCs match to companies with inferior potential economic performance compared to PVCs. In other words, an assortative matching exists in the market. It merits noting, as elaborated in Section 2.2 and Section 3.2, that the assortative matching is pair-wise stable, suggesting that VCs and companies receive higher economic values from the observed matches than they would otherwise have obtained from counterfactual matches. Overall, the existence of a stable assortative matching indicates that GVC-funded companies are those neglected by PVCs due to low expected economic returns. In other words, GVCs do not crowd out PVCs in the stage of investment selection.  

We provide further evidence for the existence of assortative matching by using a Logit model solely to estimate the outcome equation (Table 4) and then comparing the coefficient of GVC in the Logit model with that in the outcome equation of the structural model (Table 3). In the Logit model, the coefficient for GVC is $-0.2397$ , which is statistically significant at the $10\%$ level.This suggests that GVC-funded companies, on average, exhibit a lower probability of successful exit than PVC-funded companies. ### 5.2. Are GVC-funded companies potentially innovative?  

After verifying that GVCs do not crowd out PVCs in the stage of investment selection, we are concerned about whether GVCs have allocated funds for potentially innovative companies. We rerun the structural model composed of Eqs. (4) and (7); in the outcome Eq. (7), the dependent variable is Patent. Table 5 reports the estimated result.  

The coefficient for GVC in the valuation equation is $-0.3513$ , and it is statistically significant at the $1\%$ level. The negative sign indicates that companies prefer PVCs over GVCs. ### 5.3.The impacts of GVCs on companies’post-investment performance  

In the preceding sections, our results show that GVCs do not crowd out PVCs in the stage of investment selection and that they allocate funds to potentially innovative companies, meaning that GVCs bridge the equity gap left by PVCs in innovative companies. In this section, we focus on the post-investment stage and investigate the impacts of GVCs on companies’ post-investment economic and innovativeperformance.  

#### 5.3.1. Post-investment economic performance  

The outcome equation in Table 3 helps identify the causal effect of GVCs on companies' post-investment economic performance. This is because the valuation equation in Table 3 controls for the mutual selection between VC and company, and the MCMC-based Bayesian estimation provides a consistent estimate for both outcome and valuation equations. The coefficient for GvC in the outcome equation is insignificant, even at the $10\%$ level, indicating that GVCs are not significantly different from PVCs in promoting companies rates of successful exit. Our result is inconsistent with some existing China-based evidence, which shows that the postinvestment economic performance of GVC-funded companies is inferior to PVC-funded ones. Among these studies, Ke and Wang (2021) define GVC in a very similar way to ours. When we adopt a Logit model as they did, we obtain an identical result (Table 4) to theirs.  

Our result is also inconsistent with some existing evidence from the European market, which shows that the post-investment economic performance of GVC-funded companies is inferior to PVC-funded ones (Grilli and Murtinu, 2014, 2015). Below are some plausible reasons. (1) While Chinese GVC managers are also subject to relatively “fixed" pay structure, they have a stronger incentive to improve company economic performance than their European peers. This is because Chinese GVC managers have the opportunity to obtain “political promotion". In China, the board director or CEO of a SOEs, including a GVC, can be elevated to leadership roles within government departments (Zheng et al., 2012).16 (2) In China, GVCs ability to monitor and nurture funded companies differs remarkably from their European peers. To preserve and increase the value of state-owned assets and to prevent the loss of state-owned assets, the daily operation of the GVCs and their funded companies is under close monitoring of the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC) (Zhang and Mayes, 2018). Such a high level of government intervention in economic activities is beyond the reach of most governments of European countries. (3) GVCs emerged and developed earlier than PVCs in China, so GVCs are competent players in the market. Shenzhen Capital Group Co. Ltd. is an excellent example of an early and competent GVC. (4) The examination and verification system/regulation on the IPO application screening process in China grants GVCs the opportunity to use their political resources to help funded companies obtain IPO qualifications (Wang and Wu, 2020). However, Chinese GVCs also have multiple disadvantages that may limit their abilities to provide value-added services, due to strict regulations and limited discretion in investment decision-making (Zhang and Mayes, 2018). Integrating the advantages and disadvantages of GVCs, it is plausible to find that in our study both GVCs and PVCs exhibit a resemblance in their capacity to enhance companies? economic performance, as gauged by IPO/M&A outcomes. In sum, the difference between European and Chinese GVCs' performance could be attributed to their distinct institutional arrangement in the VC industry.  

The control variables in the outcome equation of Table 3 show some interesting results. The coefficient for VC experience is negative and significant at the $1\%$ level, indicating that more experienced VCs decrease companies’ exit rates. This is counterintuitive but reasonable, considering the scarcest resource for VC is time (Wang and Wang, 2011). The result seems to suggest that the more projects the VCs participate in, the less time is distributed on each project on average and thus less value-added services are provided. The coefficient for Early stage is negative and significant at the $1\%$ level, indicating that the earlier-stage companies are less likely to exit. The coefficient for High tech is positive and significant at the $5\%$ level, indicating that the companies in high-tech industries are more likely to exit than companies in low-tech industries. The coefficient for Prior patent is positive and significant at the $10\%$ level, indicating that more innovative companies are more likely to exit successfully. The coefficient for Funding size is positive and significant at the $1\%$ level, showing that companies receiving more funding in the first round are more likely to exit later. The coefficient for Investor size is positive and significant at the $1\%$ level, showing that a larger number of investors positively affects companies? exit rates, possibly due to the addition of information, resources, and expertise offered by multiple VCs. The coefficient for Exit condition is positive and significant at the $1\%$ level, suggesting companies are more likely to achieve successful exits during times of favorable market conditions. Finally, the coefficient for Marketization is significantly negative, suggesting that companies in a province with a higher level of marketization have a lower chance of exiting. The finding is consistent with Suchard et al. (2023)'s study. It seems to imply that the intense IPO or M&A competition at the provincial level adversely affects a company's likelihood of successfully exiting the market in China.

### 5.5.Heterogeneity analysis based on different types of GVCs  

Given that mixed ownership might differ from pure government ownership (Brander et al., 2015), we divide GVCs into two categories. If a GVC is wholly owned by government agencies or government-controlled business enterprises, we define it as a government-owned venture capital firm, denoted as GovC; otherwise, it is a government-supported venture capital firm, denoted as GSVC. We replace GVC in the basic regressions with GOVC and GSVC while keeping PVC as the control group. Then, we rerun the structural model in Table 3 and Table 5. The results are shown in Table 10 and Table 11.  

Table 10 shows the regression results of the structural model, in which the outcome variable is Exit. In the valuation equation, the coefficient for GOvC is negative and significant at the $5\%$ level. The negative sign indicates that GOvCs are not preferred by companies. The coefficient for GSVC is insignificant even at the $10\%$ level, indicating that companies prefer GsVCs at the same level as PVCs. One plausible explanation for the finding is that the mixed ownership offsets the deficiencies of strict government control to some extent (Suchard et al., 2021), thereby making GSVCs competitive in attracting companies. The covariance between the error terms is positive, and significant at the $10\%$ level. The positive sign of covariance means VCs prefer companies with better potential economic performance. Taken together, the revealed preferences indicate that GovCs match to the companies with inferior potential economic performance, while PVCs and GsvCs match to the companies with better potential economic performance. ### 5.6. The impacts of co-investment between GVCs and PVCs  

Bai et al. (2022) find about $50\%$ of public programs involved private investors. Given the prevalence of co-investment between GVCs and PVCs, Grilli and Murtinu (2014) present the first attempt to explicitly analyze whether the performance of GVC-backed (PVC-backed) companies could be improved by syndication activities or co-financing activities between GVCs and PVCs. Inspired by Grilli and Murtinu (2014)'s research, we control two variables, Mixed syndication and Mixed co-financing, in the basic models. As shown in Section 5.3, the impacts of both variables, Mixed syndication and Mixed co-financing, are insignificant. This evidence regarding Mixed syndication aligns with the findings of Pierrakis and Saridakis (2017), who focused on the association between mixed syndication and companies post-investment innovative performance. In this section, we further examine whether the leadership of co-investment would change the results. To this end, we decompose Mixed syndication and Mixed co-financing into four variables according to whether the lead VC firm is a GVC or a PVC.  

The new variables include the following: (1) GVC-led syndication is a dummy variable, which equals “1" if a PVC invests in the first funding round ld by a GVC; otherwise, it equals \*0. ## 6. Conclusion  

This paper investigates the effects of GVCs on supporting company innovation by answering two indivisible questions simultaneously: (1) Do GVCs crowd out PVCs in the stage of investment selection? and (2) What are the impacts of GVCs on the postinvestment performance of the funded companies compared to PVCs? We develop a two-sided matching structural model to investigate both questions simultaneously. Using Chinese VC market data from 2000 to 2020, the empirical results show that GVC-fund companies are those neglected by PVCs due to low expected economic returns, suggesting the crowding-out conjecture is not supported. Moreover, the evidence suggests that the potential innovativeness of GVC-funded companies is higher than that of PVC-funded companies, further confirming that GVCs bridge the equity gap left by PVCs in innovative companies. The results also show that in the post-investment stage, GVCs and PVCs exhibit similarities in enhancing companies' economic performance, measured by successful exit via IPO or M&A. Additionally, GVCs play a crucial role in fostering innovation among companies, leading to a higher number of patent applications generated than PVCs.

In the post-investment stage, both GOVCs and GSVCs are not significantly different from PVCs in promoting companies′ economic performance. However, GSVCs outperform PVCs and GOVCs in nurturing companies? innovation after investment. Overall, these novel findings indicate that higher government ownership leads to a higher level of social mission fulfillment in the stage of investment selection, but mixed ownership with private funding helps reduce the potential negative effects of government ownership in fostering firm innovation after investment. Both findings provide fresh insights into the existing literature concerning the influence of GVCs' ownership structure on company innovation.  

Moreover, this study examines the effects of co-investment between GVCs and PVCs, encompassing mixed syndication and mixed co-financing. We find that the company's post-investment economic performance may be enhanced by co-investment between GVCs and PVCs, but only when a GVC leads the first-round funding while PVCs co-finance in later rounds. The novel findings also suggest that if GVCs and PVCs co-invest in the first funding round, their intrinsic differences may offset the benefits of syndication. In addition, we find that co-investment, either in the format of syndication or co-financing, cannot improve the company's post-investment innovativeperformance.  

Furthermore, this study examines the heterogeneous impacts of GVCs on companies in different stages of development. Our findings indicate that early-stage companies are more likely to be funded by GVCs than late-stage companies. In addition, GVCs' positive impact on the post-investment innovative performance is particularly strong for early-stage companies. The findings imply that GVCs play a constructive role in bolstering the post-investment innovative performance of early-stage companies. Our study also recognizes the limitation of GVCs' effects in enhancing the post-investment economic performance of late-stage companies.  

This research and its findings bear important empirical implications. First, our findings justify the significant amount of investment by governments in the context of Chinese GVCs. Despite the Chinese government's significant intervention in the economy and the strong incentive and capabilities of GVCs to seek high economic returns in their investments, this paper does not present evidence of GVCs crowding out PVCs. The evidence shows that matches with PVCs have higher valuations and are ranked higher in companies’ preferences.  

Second, the sophisticated empirical results confirm that the assessment of GVCs appropriateness should start from their original purpose, i.e., funding those companies neglected by private investment. Besides comparing the post-investment economic and innovative performance of GVC-funded companies and PVC-funded companies, scholars and practitioners should also investigate whether GVCs have supported those innovative companies neglected by PVCs due to low expected economic returns. GVCs should not be criticized simply because the post-investment performance of GVC-funded companies is lower than that of PVC-funded ones.  

Third, our findings on the heterogeneous effects of GOvCs and GSVCs suggest that government agencies could adjust GVCs' ownership to serve different purposes. To address the equity gap left by PVCs in innovative companies, government agents should establish a GOvC with a pure government ownership in the investment. However, if the primary purpose is to improve companies? post-investment innovative performance, government agents should invite private equity to form a GsVC, as such mixed ownership may better nurture company innovation.  

Fourth, our findings pertinent to the effects of co-investment between GVCs and PVCs suggest that both GVCs and PVCs should consider the sequence and leadership of co-investment with each other. For instance, GVCs that led the first-round funding could consider inviting PVCs to co-invest in later rounds to help improve companies′ economic performance. In addition, the findings regarding the heterogeneous impacts of GVCs on companies in different stages of development encourage GVCs to continue their financial support to early-stage ventures, as those ventures benefit more from GVC investment.  

Despite many merits, the two-sided matching structural model suffers from some limitations that have been recognized in prior studies, and this leaves unanswered questions for future research. First, as a classical model of college admission, our two-sided matching model assumes that VCs and companies have complete information about the VC market. The simplified assumption opens a window for future studies to consider incomplete information (Bikhchandani, 2014). Second, the computational complexity of the structural model, by its nature, necessitates some compromises in the specification of the estimated model. For instance, constrained by computational tractability, we could not include interaction terms in the model (Sorensen, 2007). Future research may study the joint effects of the variables (Fox et al., 2018). Finally, the structural model applied in this study is a classical, one-to-many, two-sided matching model, and thus our conclusion is based on the gains of the lead VCs. Future studies may use the most recent manyto-many two-sided matching model and consider the investment decisions of multiple VCs (Fox et al., 2018).

Story of enhanced technology spillovers from venture capital Weike Zhang?, Xiaoli Tian, Ao $\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{u}^{\mathrm{c},*}$ a School of Public Administration, Sichuan Universty, Chengdu 610064, China SchoolfuinessiniatoouesteeitfFnaemhh School of Economics, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064, China # ARTICLEINFO # ABSTRACT Keywords: Fourth Industrial Revolution High-speed rail (HSR) Urban technological performance Venture capital (VC) As a critical infrastructure, the development of high-speed rail (HSR) inevitably exerts a marked impact on economic growth and sets the stage for different industrial revolutions. In this study, we set out an estimation framework designed to explore whether the spatial-temporal compression effect of HSR has paved the way for the Fourth Industrial Revolution characterized by urban technological innovation and whether HSR has strengthened the technology spillovers from venture capital (VC). The principal findings are as follows: First, the opening of HSR can strengthen urban technological performance, and compared with non-HSR cities, the number of patent applications is higher in HSR cities. Second, considering the heterogeneity of technological innovation, and the results show that the opening of HSR can significantly promote the breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation of cities, and has a more significant impact on the breakthrough innovation. Finally, VC has a highly significant and positive effect on urban technological performance. More notably, our findings suggest that the opening of HSR has a considerable shock effect on the technology spillovers from VC. This study has great practical significance for analyzing the impact of HSR on the transformation of the Fourth Industrial Revolution characterized by urban technological performance. ## 1. Introduction The Fourth Industrial Revolution, driven by new technologies such as artificial intelligence, big data, and robotics, has brought profound changes to all aspects of human society (Alam et al., 2020; Su et al., 2020). High-speed rail (HSR) can help speed up the transformation from third to the Fourth Industrial Revolution. As a rapidly expanding new transport mode, HSR has been a focal element of transport policies in many countries and inevitably exerts significant influences on cities and regions (Zhang et al., 2019; Bracaglia et al., 2020). In China, the achievements of HSR have attracted worldwide attention. Since the first HSR line opened in 2008, China's HSR construction has been at the forefront of the world. For example, the total operating mileage of HSR in China increases from 5.13 thousand kilometers in 2010 to 35.00 thousand kilometers in 2019, which is far surpassing any other countries (see Fig. 1). The number of bullet trains in China also increases from 4.41 thousand units in 2010 to 29.32 thousand units in 2019, with a nearly sevenfold increase (see Fig. 2). By the end of 2019, the passenger volume of HSR has accounted for $63.8\%$ of railwaypassenger volume in 2019 (see Fig. 2). The opening of HSR has dramatically shortened the geographical distance between cities, reshaped the pattern of regional economic growth, and improved the urban innovation capacity inChina. HSR can further shorten the temporal-spatial distance and improve the accessibility of cities, which may break the constraint of distance on the urban development and further affect the urban technological innovation (Li et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019a). Besides, venture capital (VC), as a particular financing method, is characterized by geographical clustering and geographical proximity (Chen et al., 2010; Guenther et al., 2018; Tian et al., 2020a; Tian et al., 2020b). In particular, China's VC institutions mainly concentrate in some developed cities, such as Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou (Long and Li, 2016). However, as the geographic distance between VC institutions and enterprises increases, the resource allocation efficiency of VC will be reduced, and the cost of information exchange between VC institutions and enterprises will be increased. Therefore, VC institutions prefer to invest the enterprises that are close to them (Belderbos et al., 2018). However, with the opening of HSR, the temporal-spatial distance between cities are further compressed, and VC institutions can easily faceto-face communication with and conduct field visits to enterprises in ![](images/90a22503b579a59d77c8fcadb87fbb09389b5f4d8496a4c05b92b66e4a508f3d.jpg) Fig. 1. The HSR operation mileage and its changes in China. Data source: Wind database https://www.wind.com.cn. ![](images/c796396112721a8551ecf51e32568e5b191d437327af921d6833bbb930f2862e.jpg) Fig. 2. Number of bullet trains and the proportion of HSR passenger volume in China. Data source: Wind database https://www.wind.com.cn. HSR cities, and thereby change the adjacent distance of investment preferences. Thus, it is of great practical significance to explore whether HSR affects the transformation of the Fourth Industrial Revolution characterized by urban technological performance. In recent years, some prior studies focus on discussing the influence of HSR to the economy and society, such as the regional economy (Dong, 2018; Bracaglia et al.,2020; Guira0 et al., 2020), the aviation industry (Chen and Wang, 2019; Li et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019b), the road and maritime transport (Calatayud et al., 2017; Aydin et al., 2018; Amin et al., 2019), the traveling time (Albalate & Fageda, 2016), and so on.Moreover, a growing number of studies explore the effect of transportation on innovation (de la Tour et al., 201l; Dong, 2018). However, to the best of our knowledge, remain limited studies have analyzed the effects of HSR in the transformation towards the Fourth Industrial Revolution characterized by urban technological performance (Ga0 and Zheng, 2020; Ji and Yang, 2020). Furthermore, up to now, far too little attention has been paid to investigate the HSR shock on the technology spillovers from VC, despite many studies investigating the determinants of innovation,such as R&D activities (Gao and Zheng, 2020), VC investment (Bertoni and Tykvova, 2015; Alvarez-Garrido and Dushnitsky, 2016). Hence, this study contributes to the literature by analyzing the impact of HSR on urban technological performance and investigating the HSR shock on the technology spil lovers of VC to cities. This study takes the opening of HSR as a quasi-natural experiment, and the main reasons are as follows: On the one hand, the construction of HSR is a national strategy, which is planned by the central government in China, but VC institutions and local governments cannot influence on the opening time and lines of HSR (Long et al., 2017). On the other hand, the Chinese HSR network mainly takes central cities such as municipalities, provincial capital cities, and sub-provincial cities as regional centers. In contrast, the opening of HSR in the non-central cities is primarily affected by the central cities, and the innovation capacity of these cities is not the main reason for HSR. This study, therefore, set out to assess the effect of HSR on urban technological performance and the technology spillovers from VC to cities using the panel data of 277 municipal-level cities in China from 2005 to 2017. The contributions of this study are given as follows: (1) We take the opening of HSR as a shock variable to investigate the impact of HSR on urban technological performance using the propensity matching score (PSM) and difference-in-difference (DID) methods. (2) We consider the heterogeneity of technological performance and divide it into breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation. We also provide empirical evidence of the impact of HSR and VC on them. (3) We further examine whether HSR affects the technology spillovers from VC to cities; that is, whether the impact of VC on urban technological performance is affected by the opening of HSR. The rest of this study is organized as follows: Section 2 presents the theoretical analysis and research hypothesis. Section 3 describes the research design, including data sources, methods, and variables. Section 4 presents the empirical analysis. Section 5 gives a further analysis of the impact of HSR on the technology spillovers from VC, and finally, the conclusions and discussions are presented in Section 6. ## 2. Theoretical analysis and research hypothesis ### 2.1. HSR and urban technological performance The technological innovation is a complicated systematic project, and it is also considered as a vital driving force for achieving highquality economic growth and the core of realizing the Fourth Industrial Transformation (Wadhwa et al., 2016). Urban technological innovation refers to the city's ability to transform new knowledge into new products, new processes, and new services. Its core is to promote the interaction and connection between innovative institutions, which is manifested as the contribution to the urban social and economic system (Wadhwa et al., 2016; Xu et al., 2018). The technological performance is usually measured by the number of patent applications, which can be divided into two sides: breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation (Clausen and Pohjola, 2013; Lahr and Mina, 2016). From the results of innovation, incremental innovation can be achieved easily through low-technology innovation, but only breakthrough innovation can represent high-quality innovation (Yueh,2009; Long and Wang, 2019). Besides, the urban innovation ability determines China's overall innovation ability to a great extent. Whereas, it is influenced by many factors, among which the distance between cities affects the flow of the urban innovation resources (Dong, 2018; Guenther et al., 2018). The spatial-temporal compression effect brought by HSR can significantly improve the accessibility level of cities. It may reshape the spatial structure and economic distribution of the urban elements, thereby may change the innovation pattern of the existing cities (Albalate and Bel, 2012). HSR may improve the accessibility and location advantage of cities (Xu et al., 2018). The construction of HSR can promote the scale of infrastructure construction along the routes and the development of related high-tech industries, such as electronics and information. Thus a large amount of capital investment can directly promote urban economic growth (Donaldson and Hornbeck, 2016). Also, HSR can compress the spatial-temporal distance between cities, and significantly reduce the commuter cost (e.g., the transport expense, the travel and waiting time, or the utility cost of the trip), and logistics transportation cost between different cities (Kong et al., 2020). In this way, HSR not only enables producers or consumers to purchase high-quality services at lower cost from further enterprises or cities, but also make it easier for enterprises to hold higher profits from broader markets that are previously unavailable (Zhang et al., 2020). Moreover, HSR can lessen the degree of information asymmetry, which is conducive to VC and other capital to layout in long-distance cities with HSR and stimulate economic growth. In summary, the opening of HSR may improve the location advantage and attracts related industries and vC, which indirectly promotes economic growth and provides the necessary economic conditions for the urban technological innovation (Ye et al., 2020). HSR can speed up the flow of human capital. The HSR network has become an essential channel for the rapid flow of elements between cities, which dramatically improves the mobility of human capital (Li et al., 2019). While the rapid flow of human capital is accompanied by the fast-moving and diffusion of production factors such as technology and capital, thus affecting urban technological innovation. Besides, the opening of HSR significantly shortens the travel time between cities, reduces the time cost of talent flow, and improves the exchange efficiency of innovative talents (Li et al., 2019). More importantly, the cross-regional flow of creative talents can promote technological exchange and knowledge spillover, which provides the necessary talent conditions for urban innovation (Ye et al., 2020). Therefore, we propose the following hypotheses: Hypothesis 1: HSR has a positive impact on urban technological performance. Hypothesis 2: HSR has different influences on breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation. ### 2.2. VC and urban technological performance VC plays a crucial role in promoting technological innovation in cities. VC can not only help enterprises to soften their financial difficulties, but also bring value-added services to entrepreneurial enterprises with its investment experience (Sonne, 2012; Wen et al., 2018; Zhang and Mayes, 2018b; Zhang et al., 2018a). Besides, VC, as a particular equity financing channel, provides financial support for emerging enterprises with development potential and promotes the rapid development and growth of enterprises (Cao et al.,2014; Belderbos et al., 2018; Takahashi et al., 2018). VC can also fund to support technological innovation and project development activities, such as R&D, patent application., and promote the improvement of technological innovation, such as the number of patents, paper trademarks, and new products (Wu and Xu, 2020). Furthermore, VC can influence urban technological innovation through avalue-addedservice mechanism (Popov and Roosenboom, 2012; Lahr and Mina, 2016). On the one hand, VC has extensive investment experience, in-depth research, and prediction of the industry development prospects. It can develop a suitable development model through strategic planning to provide advanced technology, products, and services for entrepreneurial enterprises (Devigne et al., 2013). On the other hand, as the main body of technological innovation, enterprises can utilize the VC's resources and experiences, such as extensive social relations, industrial club contacts, and bank relations, to optimize the allocation of resources and maximize the utility of VC. Also, VC can help enterprises to optimize the business structure and capital flow of enterprises, especially the optimal allocation of R&D funds, and support the research of core technology innovation and patent application. In short, VC can improve technological performance in cities by promoting the enterprises’ technological innovation (Wen et al., 2018). More recent attention has focused on the impact of VC on technological performance, and different results have been concluded. Most studies have revealed that VC has a significantly positive on technological innovation (Sun et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2019; Tian et al., 2020a). However, some studies have concluded that VC has a negative effect or no effect on technological innovation (Zucker et al.,1998; Ni et al., 2014; Lahr and Mina, 2016), but these conclusions are relatively rare. Therefore, we propose the following hypothesis: Hypothesis 3: VC has a positive impact on urban technological performance. ### 2.3. HSR and VC's technology spillovers The opening of HSR is a vital exogenous variable affecting the urban technological innovation by VC. Most VC institutions have a preference for geographical proximity and tend to invest in cities that are close to each other (Gompers and Lerner, 1999; Fritsch and Schilder, 2008). However, with the opening of HSR, the temporal and spatial distances between cities are further compressed, and vC institutions can conveniently communicate and investigate with enterprises in HSR cities (Bernstein et al., 2016). HSR also can strengthen the flexibility of faceto-face communication between VC institutions and enterprises, and effectively improve the operating efficiency of VC institutions. In particular, the opening of HSR has changed the investment preference of VC in neighboring regions (Bernstein et al., 2016). Thus, HSR can influence the distribution of VC institutions and then influence urban technological innovation and regional economic development (Guenther et al., 2018). HSR can effectively improve the resource allocation efficiency of VC and enterprises and achieve Pareto efficiency (Bernstein et al., 2016). Allocative efficiency refers to the optimal combination of input factors to produce the “optimal" combination of product quantity. Under the condition of constant input, the optimal combination and effective allocation of resources will improve the efficiency and increase the output. After the opening of HSR, the spatial-temporal distance between VC institutions and enterprises has been dramatically changed, which makes it more convenient for VC to fully understand the information of enterprises, rationally optimize resources and allocation, and provide the allocation efficiency of VC (Bernstein et al., 2016; Tian et al., 2020a). Further, HSR can reduce the cost of information exchange and communication between VC institutions and enterprises to a certain extent, and improve the flexibility of communication (Bernstein et al., 2016). Thereby, it can decrease the moral hazard and adverse selection caused by information asymmetry, accelerate the generation and development of enterprise technological innovation, and thus improve urban technological innovation and the VC's technology spillovers. Therefore, we propose the following hypothesis: Hypothesis 4: HSR has a positive effect on VC's technology spillovers. ## 3. Research design ### 3.1. Data To examine the impact of HSR on urban technological performance and the VC's technology spillovers, this study selects the panel data of 277 Chinese cities from 2005 to 2017 as samples. For the selection of samples, some cities without VC projects are excluded, and finally, the sample consists of a total of 3601 city-year observations with VC projects. We apply the number of patents (e.g., invention, utility model, and design) to measure urban technological performance, and the data are collected from the Chinese Research Data Services Platform (CNRDS) (https://www.cnrds.com). We calculate the number and investment amount of VC projects in each city according to the cities where the invested enterprises are registered, and the data are collected from the Wind database (https://www.wind.com.cn). The data of HSR is collected from the CNRDS, including the HSR station and the first opening time of HSR. The other variables, such as the economic development level, industrial structure, marketization, and financial deepening, are from the Wind database and CSMAR (http://www.gtarsc.com). Besides, in the process of data, we eliminate some city samples due to too much missing data, and some data missing in individual years are supplemented by linear interpolation. Sample matching and endogeneity processing This study uses the DID method to explore the impact of HSR on urban technological performance and VC's technology spillovers. Two fundamental problems cannot be ignored, including the absence of “counterfactual sample data” and endogenous problem. Furthermore, the DID method requires the selected samples to satisfy the “common trend"hypothesis and to prevent the choice of samples in the treatment group and the control group from producing the problem of “selective bias”(Khandker et al.,201o).To avoid the influence of the above problems, this study uses the full-sample regression and PSM method to match the treatment group and the control group (Baum and Silverman, 2004). The full-sample regression takes all non-HSR cities as the matching objects of HSR cities, which can solve the missing data of counterfactual samples but cannot solve the problem of endogeneity. While the PSM method can effectively solve the endogenous problem. In other words, it is assumed that the treatment group and the control group are similar or similar in other aspects except whether HSR is opened or not. By comparing the difference in technological performance between the treatment group and the control group, we can investigate the impact of HSR on urban technological performance. Therefore, the cities that have opened HSR are taken as the treatment group, and the cities that have not opened HSR as the control group to test the impact of the exogenous variable of HSR on urban technological performance. For the PSM method, this study selects the control variables as the feature variable to construct the control group by the 1:1 nearest matching method, and uses the logit regression to calculate the opening probability of the HSR, that is, the propensity score (PS) value. The model is defined as follows: $$ p(X_{i})=\operatorname*{Pr}[h s r_{i}=1|\mathbf{X}_{i}]=\frac{\exp(\beta\mathbf{X}_{i})}{1+\exp(\beta\mathbf{X}_{i})} $$ where $p(X_{i})$ is the propensity score; $\mathbf{X}_{i}$ is the feature variable vector affecting the opening of HSR for each city, including per capita GDP, industrial structure, market index, and the number of IPO (Initial Public Offering); $\beta$ is the coefficient of the feature variable vector; $h s r_{i}$ is the indicator variable, and $h s r_{i}$ is set to one if the city opens the HSR, otherwise it is set to zero. The PS values for each city can be calculated using Eq. (1), and then the HSR cities in the treatment group can be matched with the most similar cities without HSR from the control group using the PS values. Thus, ATT (average treatment effect on the treated) can be used to evaluate the difference of technological performance between the treatment group and the control group, and to explore whether the opening of HSR affects urban technological performance. #### 3.2.2.DID method After matching by the PSM method, the DID method is constructed to test the impact of HSR on urban technological performance. The model is set as follow: $$ Y_{i t}=\alpha_{i}+\beta_{1}h s r_{i t}\times a f t e r_{i t}+\beta_{2}\nu\tilde{c}_{i t}+\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{i}X_{i t}+\delta_{t}+\theta_{i}+\varepsilon_{i t} $$ where, $Y$ represents urban technological performance (inno), breakthrough innovation (br_inno), and incremental innovation (incr_inno); hsr and after are the dummy variable, indicating whether the city opens HSR, and before or after the opening time of HSR, respectively; hsr $\times$ after is the interaction term between the opening of HSR and the time after the opening of HSR, representing the difference of the impact of HSR on the treatment group and the control group; vc represents the variable of VC; $X$ represents the control variables, including economic development level, industrial structure, marketization level, and financial deepening degree; $\beta_{1}$ and $\beta_{2}\cdot$ represents the coefficients of the explanatory variables; $\lambda_{i}$ represents the coefficients corresponding to the control variables; i and t represent the city and year, respectively; $\delta$ represents the time effect variable; $\theta$ represents the city effect variable; $\varepsilon_{i t}$ is a random error term. ### 3.3.Variables #### 3.3.1. Technological performance FollowingthestudiesofLahr andMina,(2016), Belderbos et al. (2018), and Tian et al. (2020a), this study adopts the number of patent applications to measure urban technological performance. The reason for selecting the patent application is that the government publicly grants patents on account of their novelty and utility, and the number of patent applications can be compared horizontally and vertically. Furthermore, according to the Patent Law of the People's Republic of China, patents mainly include three different types: invention, utility model, and design. Among them, the invention-type patent represents the core technical achievements and has a higher technical level (Tian et al., 2020a). Therefore, this study not only uses the total number of patent applications to evaluate urban technological performance, but also divide it into breakthrough innovation (br_inno) and incremental innovation (incr_inno) (Clausen and Pohjola, 2013). The breakthrough innovation is measured by the total number of invention-type patent applications, and the incremental innovation is measured by the total number of utility model and design patent applications (Clausen and Pohjola, 2013). All these variables are logarithmized for reducing the bias. Since the patent applications of some cities are zero, the logarithm is taken after adding one to all the above data. #### 3.3.2. Explanatory variable HSR is set as a dummy variable, and it includes whether the city opens HSR (hsr) and before or after the opening time of HSR (after). If the city opens the HSR, $h s r=1$ ,otherwise $h s r=0$ If the time after the opening of HSR for the city, after $=1$ ,otherwise after $=0$ . The opening of HSR is measured by whether the city has HSR stations, and the opening time of HSR is mainly based on the earliest year when the city opened the HSR. VC is also an explanatory variable, which is measured by the number of VC (vc_num) and the total amount of VC (vc_mon), respectively. They are logarithmized after adding one to their values to reduce thebias. #### 3.3.3.Control variables This study controls some variables that may affect urban technological performance, and they are defined as follows: (1) Economic development (rgdp): It is defined by the logarithm of per Table2 Descriptive statistics of all variables.

Results of PSM This study uses the PSM method to match the HSR cities and nonHSR cities to ensure the reliability of the matching results. It is required that there is no systematic difference in the distribution of the covariables between the treatment group and the control group. Therefore, this study conducts the parallel trend test before the matching, that is, whether the covariables are significantly different between the treatment group and the control group. Fig. 3 presents the kernel density distribution before and after matching, and Table 3 reports the equilibrium test results of covariables. As can be seen from Fig. 3(a), before the matching, there is a significant difference in the kernel density function between the treatment group and the control group. In this case, if we directly select the HSR cities in the treatment group to compare with the non-HSR cities in the control group, the results may be biased. Besides, to the exogenous variable of HSR, there are significant differences in other factors between the two groups, which may have an impact on the technological innovation of cities. However, after PSM matching, as shown in Fig. 3(b), the kernel density distribution of the treatment group and the control group tends to coincide, indicating that the characteristics of the treatment group and the control group are similar after using the PSM. This study also carries out an equilibrium test for all covariables, and the results are shown in Table 3. Discussions and conclusions The achievements in HSR technology in China have catalyzed the transformation of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and attracted the attention of the world. The rapidly expanding of HSR will dramatically change and even revolutionize the transport mode choice to travel, and thus inevitably have a significant impact on the economic development and technological innovation of cities and regions (Xu et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2019; Bracaglia et al., 2020). Particularly, HSR further compresses the spatial-temporal distance between cities and reduces the information asymmetry between VC institutions and enterprises. Thus far, previous studies have attempted to evaluate the effect of HSR on the regional economy, the aviation industry, and the road and maritime transport. However, as far as we know, limited literature has analyzed the effects of HSR on urban technological performance, and these limited studies have tended to ignore the heterogeneity of technological performance, such as breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation. More importantly, no literature has been found on whether HSR impacts the VC's technology spillovers to cities. To address the question, we set out to explore the impact of HSR on urban technological performance using the panel data of 277 cities in China from 2005 to 2017. We first investigate whether and how HSR influences urban technological performance and other types of innovation, e.g., breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation, using the PSM-DID method, and then further examine whether the impact of VC on the city technological performance is shocked by the opening of HSR. The findings from this study make several contributions to the existing literature. This study firstly contributes to the literature by highlighting the impact of HSR on urban technological performance. Our empirical results corroborate the idea that the opening of HSR can strengthen urban technological performance. Specifically, the number of patent applications in the HSR cities is significantly higher than that in the non-HSR cities. A possible explanation for this might be that the opening of HSR can shorten the spatial-temporal distance between cities, promote the flow of talents and production factors, attract the concentration of high-quality resources such as venture capital, and thus improve urban technological innovation. The cities, therefore, should vigorously develop HSR and other transportation infrastructures to advance urban technological innovation levels and thus promote economic development. This is of considerable significance to solve the problem of the unbalanced economic development of cities. We furthermore shed new light on whether HSR has different effects on the various types of technological performance. The findings confirm that HSR can significantly enhance the breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation of cities, and has a more noticeable impact on the breakthrough innovation. More specifically, our findings suggest the number of invention-type patent applications increases significantly after the opening of HSR, and is much higher than that for utility model and design patents. This result may be explained by the fact that invention-type patents are generally considered to be more technical and core value, requiring a more significant inflow of highly skilled labor and capital investment. While HSR can shorten the spatial-temporal distance for skilled labor to travel between cities, and they will flow to HSR cities with a higher probability. Also, the opening of HSR will attract more VC and other resources, thus promoting the development of innovation activities in HSR cities. Finally, our study has also provided more in-depth insight into how HSR affects the VC's technology spillovers to cities. Our findings provide reliable empirical confirmation that both the number and total amount of VC have a highly significant and positive effect on urban technological innovation, including breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation. Notably, our study has been one of the first attempts to examine the impact of HSR on the VC's technology spillovers to cities, and our findings suggest that HSR has a significantly positive impact on technology spillovers from the total amount of VC. Specifically, after the opening of HSR, the total amount of VC can enhance the improvement of urban technological performance, including breakthrough innovation and incremental innovation. However, only the impact of the number of VC on the urban breakthrough innovation is affected by the HSR, and these results confirm again that technological innovation requires significant and long-term investments. That is to say, the opening of HSR can change the VC's proximity preference, and VC institutions are more willing to invest in enterprises in HSR cities. Compared with the non-HSR cities, the HSR cities are more likely to get long-term investment from VC, which significantly improve urban technological innovation level. Therefore, all cities should make full use of the policy dividend brought by the opening of HSR to accelerate the spillover and diffusion speed of technological knowledge and production factors, so as to improve the ability of urban technologicalinnovation. However, there are several potential limitations in this study,which may be the future research directions. First, we mainly focus on how HSR affects urban technological performance and the VC's technology spillovers to cities. Our findings show that HSR can strengthen the VC's technology spillovers to cites, but we do not discuss whether the impact of different backgrounds and strategies of VC on urban technological performance is influenced by the opening of HSR, such as government VC, private VC, foreign VC, and joint VC. Future work can further explore the impact of HSR on VC's technology spillovers from different backgrounds and strategies. Moreover, this study only takes the city level data as a research sample, which may not be enough to reveal the impact of HSR on urban technological performance and VC's technology spillovers. Future research should take into account the microdata of enterprises. Our study also does not discuss the existence of various effects in different geographical circles, such as the distance from the central city (Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen).
